## History of animals ~700 million years old
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 48%;">

* **Chemical evidence of steroids in sediment that are found in modern sponges**

<br/>

* **Accepted fossils from Ediacaran period (pre-Cambrian)**
    + mollusks, cnidarians and sponges

<br/>

* **Animals diversify across Paleozoic, Mesozoic and Cenozoic**
    + in both aquatic and terrestrial environemnts
    + punctuated by mass extinctions

</div>

## Invertebrates: lacking a backbone
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

* **95% of known animal species**

<br/>

* **Occupy every habitat on Earth**

<br/>

* **Small to huge (colossal squid)**

<br/>

* **Groupings characterized by tissue layers,symmetry and unique structures**

</div>

## Phylum Porifera (Sponges)
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Most ancestral animal group**
    + marine
    + adults do not move, larva have flagella
    + filter feeders
    + hermaphroditic (alternate sexes)
    + <span style="color:blue">lacks symmetry in body plan</span>
    
<br/>    

* **Lots of cells, but <span style="color:blue">no tissue layers</span>**
    + produce many antibiotics
    
<br/>

* **Share similarities with protist Chonaflagellates**
    + feed using cells called <span style="color:blue">*choanocytes*</span>

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:600px; WIDTH:300px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/choana3.jpg">

    + contain tissues
    
</div>    

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:550px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/cnidarian.jpg">

## Phylum Cnidarian
<hr>

<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

* **Animals except sponges are considered "True Animals"**
    + contain tissues
    
<br/>

* **First lineage to diversify were Cnidarians**
    + corals, hydras and jellyfish
    + pre-Cambrian origins
    
<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Diploblastic and radial symmetry</span>**
    + motile and sessile (non-moving)
    + polyp or medusa forms

<br/>

* **Corals have symbiotic relationships with single-celled algae**
    
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:550px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/cnidarian.jpg">

## Most animals are *triploblastic*, *bilaterians*
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:50px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:400px" SRC="images/triplo.jpg">

<div style="float: right; width: 45%;">

* **<span style="color:blue">Triploblasty</span> = 3 germ/tissue layers**

<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Complete digestive tract (most groups)</span>**
    + mouth and anus connected by tube
    
<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Bilateral</span> = symmetrical in 2 halves**
    
</div>

## Most animals are *triploblastic*, *bilaterians*
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:225px; LEFT:25px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:350px" SRC="images/triplo_phylo.jpg">

<div style="float: right; width: 45%;">

* **<span style="color:blue">Triploblasty</span> = 3 germ layers**

<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Complete digestive tract</span>**
    + mouth and anus
    
<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Bilateral</span> = symmetrical in 2 halves**
    
<br/>

* <span style="color:blue">**3 major clades of bilaterians</span>**
1. **Lophotrochozoa**
2. **Ecdysozoa**
3. **Deuterostomia**

</div>

## Lophotrochozoa: Most share 2 structures
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 40%;">

* **<span style="color:blue">Lophophore</span>: crown of ciliated tentacles for feeding**

<br/>
<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Trophophore</span>: distinctive larval stage**
    + beating cilia
    + cylinder body

<br/>

* **This group is falling apart with new molecular-based phylogenies**    
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:225px; LEFT:475px; WIDTH:600px; HEIGHT:400px" SRC="images/lopho.jpg">

## Lophotrochozoa - 18 total phyla
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

* **Key phyla (18 total):**
1. Platyhelminthes (flatworms)
2. Syndermata (rotifers)
3. Brachiopods (lamp shells)
4. Mollusca (snails, slugs, oysters, clams, octopuses, squids)
5. Annelids (segmented worms)

<br/>

* **Many phyla appeared in Cambrian explosion**

## Ecdysozoans
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: right; width: 50%;">

* **Animals with cuticle**
    + shed tough external coat
    + shed as grow; <span style="color:blue">molting; *ecdysis*</span>
    
<br/>

* **8 total phyla**
    + more species than all other groups
    
<br/>

* **2 major phyla**
1. Nematoda (roundworms)
2. Arthropods (mostly insects)

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:50px; WIDTH:450px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/bugs.jpg">

## Phylum Nematoda (round worms)
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Cylinder bodies from 1mm to 1m**

<br/>

* **Aquatic, soil, plant tissues, animals tissues**
    + many parasitic species (crop pests)
    + humans are host to ~50 species!

<br/>

* **Longitudinal muscles; thrashing motion**

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:275x; LEFT:510px; WIDTH:550px; HEIGHT:300px" SRC="images/nematode.jpg">

## Phylum Arthropoda: Rulers of the animal world
<hr>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **A billion billion arthropods estimated**
    + 1 million species described
    + nearly all habitats on Earth
    
<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Segmented body, hard exoskeleton, jointed appendages</span>**
    + likely led to success
    
<br/>

* **Early arthropods (*Trilobites*) had little variation in body plan**

<br/>

* **Evolution selected for functional body regions**
    + head, thorax, abdomen
    + each with specialized functions

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:600px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/trilobyte.jpg">
